FacilityName: Baxter Healthcare of Puerto Rico LLC

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES - CHLORINE KIT B

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Baxter Healthcare of Puerto Rico (Baxter) manufacture inhaled anesthetics in its facilities located in Route 3, Km. 144.2, in Guayama, Puerto Rico. Its NAICS code is 32541.

Baxter Guayama is committed with the protection of the environment, health and safety of our employees and neighbors. The EHS (Environmental, Health and Safety) Director reports to the corporate EHS Pharma Section Director and also to the Site Director and assure that every job, task, project, etc. that will be perform has been evaluate in term of EHS.  

For the Process Safety Program and Risk Management Program roles and responsibilities are defined to assure all changes and repairs are completed following Good Engineering Practices and following RAGAGEP. 

Baxter has policies and local procedures that defined programs to prevent accidental release and to respond to any emergency in the case that would be necessary. Senior management jobs description defined roles and responsibilities to ensure compliance with EHS regulations.    

Baxter Guayama manufactures three types of anesthesia: Isoflurane, Desflurane, Sevoflurane.  Chlorine and Hydrofluoric Acid are used in the manufacturing reaction process.   

1)   Hydrofluoric Acid, Anhydrous 100 % CAS No. 7664-39-3:
This substance is found above threshold limits in the manufacturing process known as Desflurane and Sevoflurane. 

There is a storage tank for the substance (8,000 gallons), from this tank each manufacturing process transfer the substance to a Shot Pot (transfer vessel). There is one shot pot for the Desflurane Process and one for the Sevoflurane process. From the Shot Pot the substance is transfer to the Fluorination Reactor. Tanks are connected to an emergency scrubber system. At the Desflurane process there are two Fluorination Reactors although only one can be used at a time in the reaction step. At the Sevoflurane process there is one Fluorination reactor.  Also, an Iso-container is included in this process (42,240 lbs) because t

he iso-container could be store temporarily at site until QA Release completed for transference.

 2)  Chlorine CAS No. 7782-50-5

This chemical is handled as a liquefied gas in 1,995.4 lbs. pressurized cylinders. Chlorine above its threshold limit is managed at the storage rack where a maximum of 55,971 lbs may be present. Both manufacturing process, Isoflurane and Sevoflurane, used the Chlorine in their respective Chlorination reactions. For each process there is a Chlorine Room in which the Chlorine cylinders are connected to the process system. These rooms are closed and are connected to an Emergency Scrubber.  

Additional to compliance with 40 CFR part 68  Risk Management Program Baxter, general accident release prevention program also ensure compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management (PSM), and 6 CFR Part 27 Department of Homeland Security.   

Being subject to PSM requirements, all covered process fall under Program 3 Prevention Program. 

Employees have the opportunity to participate in different forums and meetings to communicate their ideas to improve the program. Also, they participate in incidents investigations, training, operational procedures, and process hazard analysis. 

Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's) and Material Batch records (MBR's) describe specific steps to perform the process.  Includes safety information and controls (administrative, engineering, personal protective equipment) to ensure process do not affect employees and neighbors. Training related to SOP's and MBR's are provided in a regular basis or when process is impacted by the changes.  Training curriculum is assigned to employees based on their roles and responsibilities.  

Management of Change program includes evaluation for changes related to the process.  A major change like tank replacement that complies with replacement in kind definition is also evaluated.   As part of the evaluation process hazard analysis may be required before change is executed. Also

, Pre-start up safety review (PSSR) may be required if defined as part of the evaluation process. 

Process Hazard Analysis is performed according to the regulation or more often if a change impact the process safety.  Risks and Hazards are identified as part of the analysis for each element of the process.

Baxter contractor roles and responsibilities are defined as part of the contractor safety procedure.  Contractor performance is evaluated each year. Also, annually a meeting is coordinated with Contractor personnel to ensure they know Baxter safety rules. Each contractor has to complete annually a training offered by Baxter personnel where safety rules are reviewed.  As part of the selection process Contractor's Safety program and training evidence is evaluated.  

Baxter Safety Programs includes procedures related to Lockout Out/Tag Out, Hot Work Permit, Confined space entry, between others, that help to keep process in control during routinely and non-routinely activities. 

Mechanical integrity program includes preventive maintenance, calibration and inspection for process critical equipment's. Safety systems like alarms, fire system is verified as part of the program. Shutdowns are scheduled throughout the year. Mechanical Integrity Testing is conducted based on the requirements by applicable codes, standards and regulations by specialized contractors and onsite personnel. 

Compliance audits are regularly conducted and comply with RMP Program elements. 

In the past five years Baxter didn't have any reportable accident as per RMP requirement.  Baxter has a program for Accident and or Incident Investigation in which incidents are notified and investigated.  Not only incidents and or accidents related to environmental release also related to safety, property damage, product loss, security, occupational health and near misses are investigated as part of the program and corrective and preventive actions are defined. 

The emergency response program consists of

several elements like: Organization and Procedure for Fire Control, Hurricane Emergency Plan, Emergency Evacuation Alarms, and Procedure for Area and Emergency Meeting Point Coordinators.

As part of the Baxter emergency system employees from different shift and areas are trained in emergency response to fire, spill, etc.   As part of the training program classroom training and drill are provided like Chlorine Kit B, Level A, SCBA, HAZWOPER, Fire Extinguisher, Confined Space, etc. 

Local agencies like Fire Department know information about our facility through SPCC, SWPP Plan and other EPA required reports. At this moment LEPC didn't have periodic meetings but Baxter keep local agencies informed in case an accident affects the community or neighbors.    Annually Baxter performed drills in coordination with local agencies and neighbors.
 
Baxter provide specific trainings to Baxter personnel in order to increase knowledge related to response to emergencies that can affect not only our employees but also our neighbors. 

When compared this resubmission with 2019 submittal the covered process, no new storage tank or area was built. However, the backyard area was included as part of the process since the area is used to store ISO Containers of HF and Containers of Chlorine. As part of the PHA revalidations this area was considered and PSM/RMP boundaries were extended.
